Article.ArticleTitle: Time-Resolved Measurements of Nitric Oxide, Nitrogen Dioxide, and Nitrous Acid in an Occupied New York Home.

AbstractText: Indoor oxidizing capacity in occupied residences is poorly understood. We made simultaneous continuous time-resolved measurements of ozone (O<sub>3</sub>), nitric oxide (NO), nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>), and nitrous acid (HONO) for two months in an occupied detached home with gas appliances in Syracuse, NY. Indoor NO and HONO mixing ratios were higher than those outdoors, whereas O<sub>3</sub> was much lower (sub-ppbv) indoors. Cooking led to peak NO, NO<sub>2</sub>, and HONO levels 20-100 times greater than background levels; HONO mixing ratios of up to 50 ppbv were measured. Our results suggest that many reported NO<sub>2</sub> levels may have a large positive bias due to HONO interference. Nitrous acid, NO<sub>2</sub>, and NO were removed from indoor air more rapidly than CO<sub>2</sub>, indicative of reactive removal processes or surface uptake. We measured spectral irradiance from sunlight entering the residence through glass doors; hydroxyl radical (OH) production rates of (0.8-10) × 10<sup>7</sup> molecules cm<sup>-3</sup> s<sup>-1</sup> were calculated in sunlit areas due to HONO photolysis, in some cases exceeding rates expected from ozone-alkene reactions. Steady-state nitrate radical (NO<sub>3</sub>) mixing ratios indoors were predicted to be lower than 1.65 × 10<sup>4</sup> molecules cm<sup>-3</sup>. This work will help constrain the temporal nature of oxidant concentrations in occupied residences and will improve indoor chemistry models.
